title: Colors Trap Foreshadows Haki and Willpower
theoryText: Miss Goldenweek's Colors Trap ability, which is explicitly NOT a Devil Fruit power, introduces the concept that willpower and mental strength matter in One Piece. The fact that 'simple-minded' people like Luffy are more vulnerable, while strong-willed individuals could resist, may be early foreshadowing of Conqueror's Haki and the importance of willpower that becomes central to the series later.
author: Various One Piece fans
evidenceFromEpisode: Miss Goldenweek states that simple-minded people like Luffy are more vulnerable to Colors Trap, establishing that mental fortitude is a tangible power in the One Piece world.

title: Miss Goldenweek is the Most Underrated Baroque Works Agent
theoryText: Despite being a child with no Devil Fruit powers or combat abilities, Miss Goldenweek is arguably the most effective Baroque Works agent shown in Little Garden. She completely neutralizes Luffy—the strongest fighter present—without throwing a single punch. This demonstrates that in One Piece, raw power isn't everything, and that creative abilities and tactics can be more valuable than strength.
author: One Piece community discussions
evidenceFromEpisode: Miss Goldenweek uses Colors Trap to completely control Luffy's actions and emotions, preventing him from saving his friends despite his superior physical strength and Devil Fruit powers.

title: Colors Trap Could Have Defeated Any Enemy in Early One Piece
theoryText: If Colors Trap works on someone as strong-willed as Luffy (even if he is 'simple-minded'), it could theoretically work on almost anyone in the East Blue and early Grand Line. The only reason it isn't overpowered is because it requires the target to be marked with paint, which is difficult in active combat. This makes Miss Goldenweek a support fighter who needs teammates to hold enemies still.
author: One Piece theorists
evidenceFromEpisode: Luffy is completely helpless once painted with Colors Trap symbols, unable to break free without outside help. The only limitation is that Miss Goldenweek needs an opening to paint the symbols.

title: Little Garden Sets Up Elbaf's Importance
theoryText: The Little Garden arc, including episodes like 75, introduces the Giants Dorry and Brogy and their homeland of Elbaf. This arc establishes Elbaf as a significant location that Usopp dreams of visiting. Fans theorize this early setup means Elbaf will be a major arc later in the series, possibly near the endgame, and Usopp's connection to the giants will pay off in a major way.
author: One Piece community
evidenceFromEpisode: While not directly in Episode 75, the Little Garden arc extensively features the giant warriors and their culture, with Usopp expressing admiration for their warrior spirit.

title: Color Psychology in One Piece is Based on Real Science
theoryText: Miss Goldenweek's Colors Trap ability is based on real-world color psychology theory, which suggests that different colors can influence human emotions and behavior (red for aggression, blue for sadness, green for calm, etc.). Oda may have incorporated actual psychological research into this ability, making it one of the more 'realistic' powers in One Piece despite being hypnosis-based.
author: One Piece analysts
evidenceFromEpisode: Each Colors Trap technique uses colors traditionally associated with specific emotions: red (aggression/bullfighting), yellow (happiness/laughter), blue (sadness), green (calm), black (betrayal/darkness).
